content.title: Dialysis Initiation
content.summary: Clinical decision-making framework for when to initiate renal replacement therapy in patients with advanced CKD, balancing uremic symptoms, metabolic complications, and patient preferences against risks of early dialysis
key_points: No fixed GFR threshold—decisions should be individualized based on symptoms
Classic urgent indications: AEIOU (Acidosis, Electrolytes, Intoxication, Overload, Uremia)
IDEAL trial showed no survival benefit to early (GFR 10-14) vs late (GFR 5-7) initiation
Most patients start when GFR 5-10 mL/min with symptoms
Timely vascular access or PD catheter placement is critical (6+ months before needed)
Shared decision-making should include transplant, conservative management options
Preparation includes access creation, modality education, dietary counseling

statement.text: Dialysis initiation in chronic kidney disease is a clinical decision based on the presence of uremic symptoms, metabolic complications refractory to medical management, or quality of life impairment—not solely on GFR thresholds. The IDEAL trial demonstrated that early initiation (GFR 10-14) provides no survival advantage over symptom-based initiation (typically GFR 5-7). Timely preparation including vascular access creation, modality education, and shared decision-making significantly impacts outcomes.
statement.formal: Dialysis initiation = Uremic symptoms OR Refractory hyperkalemia/acidosis/overload OR Quality of life impairment NOT based solely on GFR

explanation.intuition: Starting dialysis is not like starting a medication—it fundamentally changes the patient's life. There's no survival benefit to starting 'early,' so the goal is to delay dialysis until symptoms demand it, while preparing adequately so the transition is smooth. Think of it as an elective decision whenever possible, not an emergency.
explanation.key_insight: The IDEAL trial was a game-changer: it showed that patients randomized to early dialysis (GFR 10-14) had no survival benefit over those starting when symptomatic (GFR 5-7). Many 'early' starters began dialysis feeling well and lost quality of life unnecessarily. Current practice favors symptom-based initiation with excellent preparation.
explanation.technical_details: Preparation timeline: Referral to nephrology at GFR <30; access planning at GFR <20 (fistula creation takes 3-6 months to mature); modality education at GFR 15-20; transplant evaluation if eligible. Urgent indications for dialysis: refractory acidosis (pH <7.1), hyperkalemia (K >6.5 with ECG changes despite medical therapy), volume overload (pulmonary edema refractory to diuretics), uremic encephalopathy, pericarditis, bleeding.

definitions_glossary.end_stage_renal_disease: CKD stage 5 (GFR <15 mL/min) with need for renal replacement therapy
definitions_glossary.renal_replacement_therapy: Treatment to replace kidney function: hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or transplant
definitions_glossary.uremic_symptoms: Clinical manifestations of uremia: nausea, anorexia, fatigue, encephalopathy, pericarditis
definitions_glossary.arteriovenous_fistula: Surgical connection between artery and vein creating vascular access for hemodialysis
definitions_glossary.peritoneal_dialysis: RRT modality using peritoneum as dialysis membrane with indwelling catheter
definitions_glossary.incremental_dialysis: Starting with less than full-dose dialysis, increasing as residual kidney function declines
definitions_glossary.conservative_management: Supportive care without dialysis—appropriate for some patients with limited life expectancy
definitions_glossary.vascular_access: Means of accessing circulation for hemodialysis (fistula, graft, or catheter)
definitions_glossary.uremic_pericarditis: Pericardial inflammation due to uremic toxins—absolute indication for dialysis
definitions_glossary.uremic_encephalopathy: Altered mental status, asterixis from uremic toxin accumulation
definitions_glossary.residual_renal_function: Remaining native kidney function—preserved longer with PD than HD
definitions_glossary.dialysis_modality_education: Patient education about HD, PD, home HD, transplant options

pathophysiology.mechanism: As GFR declines below 15 mL/min, uremic toxins accumulate, causing multi-system symptoms. The kidney's ability to maintain fluid, electrolyte, and acid-base homeostasis progressively fails. Dialysis artificially removes toxins and excess fluid that the kidneys can no longer excrete. However, dialysis does not replicate endocrine functions (erythropoietin, vitamin D activation), which require separate management.

clinical_manifestations_of_uremia.general: Fatigue, weakness, malaise, weight loss, anorexia
clinical_manifestations_of_uremia.neurologic: Encephalopathy (confusion, asterixis), peripheral neuropathy, restless legs
clinical_manifestations_of_uremia.gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, metallic taste, hiccups

urgent_indications_aeiou.acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis (pH <7.1) refractory to bicarbonate therapy
urgent_indications_aeiou.electrolytes: Hyperkalemia (K >6.5) with ECG changes despite medical management
urgent_indications_aeiou.intoxication: Dialyzable toxin ingestion (lithium, methanol, ethylene glycol, salicylates)
urgent_indications_aeiou.overload: Volume overload with pulmonary edema refractory to diuretics

elective_initiation_criteria: Symptomatic uremia (nausea, anorexia, fatigue) impairing quality of life
Inability to maintain adequate nutrition despite dietary modification
Refractory hyperkalemia or acidosis with less aggressive treatment
Declining functional status attributable to uremia
Usually occurs at GFR 5-10 mL/min based on symptoms
what_not_to_do: Do not initiate solely based on GFR threshold (no benefit shown for GFR >5-7)
Do not wait until emergent—plan ahead for optimal access and modality
Do not ignore patient preferences—shared decision-making is essential

timeline: GFR <30: Refer to nephrology, begin education
GFR <20: Discuss modalities, transplant referral if eligible
GFR 15-20: Create AV fistula (takes 3-6 months to mature) or plan PD catheter
GFR <10: Intensify symptom monitoring, finalize modality choice

vascular_access_options.av_fistula: Gold standard—lowest infection/thrombosis; requires 3-6 month maturation
vascular_access_options.av_graft: Alternative if poor vessels; matures in 2-4 weeks; higher complication rate
vascular_access_options.central_venous_catheter: For urgent/unplanned starts; highest infection risk; avoid if possible

pd_preparation.training: Patient/caregiver trained on exchanges, sterile technique

hemodialysis.in_center: 3×/week, 3-4 hours; healthcare team performs; most common in US
hemodialysis.home_hd: More frequent, shorter sessions or nocturnal; improves outcomes
hemodialysis.patient_factors: Requires vascular access; may not suit patients with poor access/cardiovascular instability

peritoneal_dialysis.advantages: Home-based, preserves residual function, no needles, dietary flexibility
peritoneal_dialysis.patient_factors: Requires manual dexterity, clean home environment; not for prior abdominal surgery

conservative_management.indication: Patients with limited life expectancy, poor prognosis, or preference against dialysis
conservative_management.approach: Symptom management, advance care planning, hospice involvement

incremental_dialysis.concept: Start with less-than-full dose dialysis, increase as residual function declines
incremental_dialysis.rationale: Preserves residual function, maintains quality of life, reduces treatment burden
incremental_dialysis.monitoring: Regular assessment of residual GFR, symptoms, solute clearance

definition.@value: Clinical decision-making framework for when to begin renal replacement therapy in patients with end-stage renal disease, based on symptoms and complications rather than fixed GFR thresholds

skos.scopeNote: Covers urgent and elective indications, preparation timeline, vascular access planning, modality selection, and shared decision-making
skos.example: A 72-year-old with CKD stage 5 (GFR 8), well-functioning AV fistula, presenting with worsening fatigue, anorexia, and nausea despite conservative measures—appropriate candidate for dialysis initiation

learning_objectives: Identify urgent indications for dialysis using AEIOU mnemonic
Apply symptom-based rather than GFR-based initiation criteria
Outline the preparation timeline for optimal dialysis start
Compare hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis modalities
Engage patients in shared decision-making about RRT options
clinical_pearls: IDEAL trial: early dialysis (GFR 10-14) showed NO survival benefit—start when symptomatic
AV fistula is best access; plan creation at GFR 15-20, not when dialysis is imminent
Patients starting with a catheter have worse outcomes—avoid 'crash starts'
Conservative management is a valid option for some—don't assume all patients want dialysis
Uremic pericarditis is an ABSOLUTE indication—can progress to tamponade
Residual kidney function matters—preserved longer with PD than HD

board_yield.internal_medicine_boards: High - AEIOU indications, timing, modality selection
board_yield.nephrology_boards: Very High - nuanced timing, access planning, IDEAL trial

common_misconceptions: Dialysis should start at a specific GFR (e.g., 10)—false; symptom-based is preferred
Earlier is always better—false; IDEAL showed no benefit and possible harm from early start
All patients should receive dialysis—false; conservative management is appropriate for some

sources.source: Cooper BA, et al. A randomized, controlled trial of early versus late initiation of dialysis (IDEAL study). N Engl J Med. 2010;363(7):609-19
sources.relevance: Landmark trial showing no benefit of early dialysis initiation
